title: How are karaoke tracks made? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are referring to movie songs that don’t have the vocals and how they are made - usually vocals reside in the center of the song. Use Audacity Open the MP3 fileSplit the stereo song into 2 tracksInvert one of the tracksConvert both tracks to monoAnother way to do this is to use Vocal Remover from the menu. You may additionally use Compression and EQ to further eliminate some frequencies. However, bear in mind, these processes do not always work on all songs - if there are effects such as Reverb, Delay they could bleed into other tracks or the vocals could creep into other tracks thereby leaving some traces of vocals after the above process. Removing too much vocals could take away some instruments from the center as well. There are plenty of tutorial videos on YouTube on how to eliminate vocals from a song. Please check out my new YouTube channel - youtube.com/MobileMusic HTH

“Karaoke track” can refer to any musical rendition of a song sans vocals, from MIDI files, to original tracks that have the vocals “removed,” to professionally re-created renditions of songs. I am going to assume you’re referring to karaoke tracks that you can buy from a store, or that you can find being used by DJs in bars. These tracks are (99% of the time) not the original tracks, but professional re-creations of the original music that are made to sound like the original recordings. Some companies do this very well, where you usually cannot hear the difference. Other companies do a horrible job and create tracks that do not sound even close to the original. However, even with the good ones, if you listen closely, you can hear very subtle differences from the original track and the karaoke track.

Yes, it can be done, and there will be residual voice on the recording. Get a stereo MP3 of the song. ...Import the MP3 to a new project in Audacity. ...Verify that the track is a stereo track. ...Select a part of the song with vocals to test. ...Open the “Effects” menu. ...Select “Vocal Reduction and Isolation” from the menu. ...Set your vocal reduction parameters.
